docs.lead_paragraph: For some years now, scientists have been debating whether there is any evidence to show that environmental problems may be causing a significant decline in the quality of human sperm, posing a threat to fertility. New findings by researchers at the University of Southern California's Keck School of Medicine suggest that, at least for American men, there may be no grounds for worry.

headline.main: American Sperm, as Hardy as Ever

docs.abstract: New study by researchers at University of Southern California's Keck School of Medicine finds that quality of American men's sperm is as high as that seen in men in landmark study 59 years ago; there had been concern that environmental problems may be causing significant decline in quality of human sperm (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A test of 13 brands of a popular herbal product, Sam-e, found that only seven had contents in keeping with the label, according to Consumerlab.com, an online independent group that tests supplements sold in this country. A synthetic version of a chemical that naturally occurs in the body, Sam-e is used to treat depression and osteoarthritis.

headline.main: 6 of 13 Herbal Brands Fail a Label Test

docs.abstract: Consumerlab.com, online independent group that tests supplements sold in US, reports that test of 13 brands of popular herbal product, Sam-e, finds that only seven had contents in keeping with label (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Psychologists have long praised the family meal as an opportunity for conversation and bonding. Now a large Harvard study shows that children who eat with their parents frequently may have healthier eating habits than those who rarely do. The study, which included more than 16,000 children of nurses and was published this month in Archives of Family Medicine, found that children who had family meals were one and a half times as likely to eat five servings of fruits and vegetables every day as those who rarely ate with parents. A nutritional analysis of the diets showed that children who ate with their parents frequently had the highest intake of many important nutrients, like calcium, fiber, folate, iron and vitamins B and E.

headline.main: Linking Children's Health to Family Meals

docs.lead_paragraph: The greater the number of passengers in a car driven by a 16- or 17-year-old, the higher the risk of a fatal car crash, a new study reports. The findings appear in The Journal of the American Medical Association, and the authors urge greater use of graduated licensing systems that restrict young drivers' ability to carry passengers. The lead author, Li-Hui Chen of the School of Public Health at Johns Hopkins, said researchers could only speculate about explanations, but the study noted earlier research that linked reckless driving and peer pressure. Her study did not determine how many of the teenagers had been drinking or the precise role the passengers might have played in the crashes.

headline.main: Adding to the Risk for Teenage Drivers

docs.abstract: New study finds that the greater the number of passengers in a car driven by 16- or 17-year old, higher the risk of a fatal car crash (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The removal of the diabetes drug Rezulin from the market did not come soon enough to help Monica George, a 68-year-old former nurse in Rockville, Md.: It had already caused her death, her daughters said. But the drug's removal upset Frank Hopkins, a Virginia horse-farm owner, who said it greatly improved his health and brought his diabetes under control. The removal of the drug by the Food and Drug Administration last week brought anger, confusion and a stream of questions. Doctors and patients alike asked whether the agency had approved the drug too quickly, without regard to the severe liver damage it could cause. When liver failure and deaths began to occur, did the agency act too slowly in removing the drug? If so, why?

headline.main: Removal of Diabetes Drug Meets With Mixed Feelings

docs.lead_paragraph: With an electronic microchip implanted in his back, Marc Merger, of Strasbourg, France, is now able to take a few halting steps for the first time in 10 years. Mr. Merger, 38, had been immobilized since his spinal cord was severed in a car crash. In a project involving six European nations, the I.B.M. Corporation and French scientists, Mr. Merger's leg muscles were stimulated by electronic charges fired by a program stored in the chip. ''His first step was very difficult -- to get those muscles moving after all that time,'' said

docs.lead_paragraph: It is rare indeed for commercial television to produce a program of such high quality and importance as the two-and-a-half-hour documentary, ''Cancer: Evolution to Revolution,'' to be shown at 8 p.m. Eastern time this Thursday on HBO. Produced and directed by Joseph F. Lovett, five of whose family members had cancer and four of whom died of it, the film is at once realistic and hopeful about the life-and-death battles being waged daily against this disease. Recognizing the need for as many Americans as possible to view this extraordinary, information-packed effort by Mr. Lovett, who is also the film's host, HBO is asking its affiliates to make it available to all cable subscribers, even those who do not have access to HBO, and will show it three more times: on April 5 at 4:30 p.m., on April 8 at 10 a.m. and on April 17 at 2:30 p.m. on its regular subscriber channel. If you do not have cable, I urge you to visit a friend who does or ask someone to tape it for you.

docs.lead_paragraph: When her father died from leukemia, 3-year-old Rachel asked her mother, ''When is he coming back?'' Mark, 7, complained of chest pains after his father died, and took to wearing his father's boxer shorts and ties. ''He is gone, kaput, he's dead,'' Mark explained to a family friend.

headline.main: Experts Offer Fresh Insights Into the Mind of the Grieving Child

docs.abstract: Experts offer fresh insights into the mind of grieving child; new book, Healing Children's Grief: Surviving a Parent's Death From Cancer, by Dr Grace Hyslop Christ, makes it clear that children, even very young children, do grieve, even though their grieving differs at different ages, and often bears little resemblance to mourning reactions of adults; Christ comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a world of heart bypass surgery, angioplasty and beta blockers, maybe aspirin just doesn't have the high-tech cachet that patients want. Whatever the reason, a new study has determined that only a quarter of patients with heart disease are regularly taking aspirin, even though experts agree that it helps prevent new heart attacks and other problems.

headline.main: A Lifesaver That Often Goes Unused
